Details.Description: This file includes the persona of an individual interviewed using the Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD) framework for a new product. It also contains the full transcript of the qualitative interview, documenting the conversation between the interviewer and the individual.

persona.name: Morgan Johnson
persona.background_story: Morgan grew up in a small town in Oregon, where her parents taught her the importance of hard work and community service from an early age. After high school, Morgan was determined to pursue a career in nursing, inspired by her grandmother who was a nurse during World War II. Over the years, she has worked in various hospitals, always bringing compassion and dedication to her job. Her career has been influenced by her desire to provide care and support to those in need, shaped further by her humble beginnings and the stories of resilience shared by her family.

demographics.mobility: Owns car, uses public transport occasionally

psychographics.values_and_beliefs: Morgan values family, honesty, and hard work above all. She believes in the power of community and the importance of giving back.
hobbies_and_interests: Volunteering at the local animal shelter

behavioral_traits.emotional_resilience: Morgan handles stress well, recovering quickly from setbacks by focusing on solutions rather than problems.

emotional_triggers.positive_triggers: Being appreciated for her work and seeing positive outcomes from her care.

motivations.emotional_motivations: Feeling appreciated and seeing her patients recover successfully.
motivations.intrinsic_motivations: Passion for helping others and curiosity about medical advancements.

challenges.personal_challenges: Balancing work with family responsibilities and maintaining health.
challenges.professional_challenges: Keeping up with industry trends and technological advancements.
challenges.communication_challenges: Occasional discomfort with confrontation and expressing emotions.

life_outside_work.social_circle: Has a tight-knit group of close friends and family.

family_life.importance_of_family: Central to her identity; family is her main motivator.

life_outside_work.community_involvement: Regularly volunteers at the local animal shelter and participates in community health fairs.

professional_goals.short_term_goals: Earn a certification in advanced geriatric care.
professional_goals.long_term_goals: Transition to a mentorship role, guiding new nurses.

frustrations_pain_points.personal_frustrations: Limited time for relaxation and self-care.
frustrations_pain_points.professional_frustrations: Bureaucratic hospital policies that slow down patient care.
frustrations_pain_points.communication_frustrations: Feeling misunderstood during discussions with superiors.

daily_tasks.personal_routine: Morning yoga, prepare meals, spend time with family in the evenings.
daily_tasks.work_routine: Check patient reports, administer medication, provide patient care and support.

social_media_usage.purpose: Networking and staying connected with family.

cognitive_biases.optimism_bias: Believes in her ability to make a difference in patient lives.
cognitive_biases.confirmation_bias: Tends to favor information that aligns with her nursing guidelines.
cognitive_biases.anchoring_bias: Decisions often influenced by past successful treatments.
cognitive_biases.availability_bias: Frequently recalls stories of past patients to guide current care strategies.

response_tendencies.level_of_disclosure: Open to sharing professional insights but reserved with personal details.

response_to_interview_context.adaptability_during_interviews: Adjusts well to new topics, especially those related to healthcare.

customer_journey.awareness_stage: Learns about healthcare products through workshops and training sessions.
customer_journey.consideration_stage: Weighs recommendations from colleagues and reviews recent studies.
customer_journey.decision_stage: Quality and peer recommendations are crucial.
customer_journey.post_purchase_behavior: Advocates for products that improve efficiency and patient care.

transcript.text:
Hello, thank you for joining me today. I appreciate you taking the time to participate in this interview. My name is [Your Name], and I'm here to learn more about your experiences and preferences when it comes to footwear, particularly in your professional role as a nurse. Your honest and in-depth responses will be invaluable for this study.

To start us off, could you please tell me a little bit about your background and your daily routine as a nurse?

Hi, thanks for having me. Sure, I'd love to share a bit about my background. I'm Morgan Johnson, a registered nurse living in Seattle. I grew up in a small town in Oregon and always felt inspired by my grandmother, who was a nurse during World War II. 

As for my daily routine, it usually starts with some morning yoga to get me centered. At work, I begin by checking patient reports and then administering medication and providing care and support throughout the day. I try to balance my professional duties with my family responsibilities, spending quality time with them in the evenings. It can be a juggling act sometimes!

Thank you for sharing that, Morgan. It sounds like you have a very fulfilling and demanding routine! Let's talk a bit more about how your daily routine influences your footwear choices. 

Can you describe your daily routine as a nurse and how it affects your choice of footwear?

Definitely! Since I'm on my feet a lot during my shifts, having comfortable and supportive footwear is really important for me. My routine involves a lot of walking, standing, and sometimes quick movements, so I look for shoes that can support all-day wear without causing discomfort. I need shoes that have good arch support and cushioning to help prevent foot fatigue. Durability is also key because I'm always on the move and I need them to last. So, basically, when choosing footwear, I prioritize comfort and support to keep me going throughout my busy days.

I see. Comfort and support are clearly essential for you. You mentioned needing good arch support and cushioning to prevent foot fatigue. Could you elaborate on any specific challenges or discomforts you’ve faced with the shoes you currently use?

Sure, I've had a few challenges with shoes in the past. Sometimes, I find that even when shoes start out comfortable, they can wear out quickly, losing their cushioning and support. This can lead to sore feet and sometimes even back pain, especially after a long shift. Occasionally, shoes that initially seem to fit well might rub in certain areas or cause blisters as the day goes on. So, finding shoes that maintain their comfort over time and have a truly supportive design is always a priority for me.

Thank you for sharing those experiences. It sounds like wear and tear is a significant issue, along with the need for consistent support throughout your shifts. 

Can you recall a specific time when the choice of your footwear impacted your work performance? How did it affect you?

Yes, I remember a day when I wore a pair of shoes that I thought were comfortable enough, but as the shift went on, they started to pinch and rub in the wrong places. By the end of the day, my feet were really sore and it affected my mood and energy levels. I found it harder to focus and had to take more breaks than usual just to relieve the discomfort. It reminded me how crucial it is to have reliable footwear, as it really does impact my ability to care for my patients effectively.

That sounds like a tough experience, and it's clear how much footwear can impact your performance and well-being.

How do your feet typically feel at the end of your shift, especially on days when your footwear performs well versus when it doesn't?

When my footwear is doing its job well, my feet feel a bit tired at the end of the shift, but not in pain. I might have a bit of soreness, which is kind of expected after being on my feet all day, but nothing too bad. On the days when my footwear falls short, my feet feel achy and sore, sometimes even swollen, which can make the rest of the evening uncomfortable. It really makes a big difference in how I feel post-shift.

Thank you for providing that detailed comparison; it really helps highlight the difference that good footwear can make.

Now, moving on to another aspect of your experience, how important is the style of footwear to you in a professional setting?

In a professional setting, style isn't my top priority compared to comfort and support, but it's still nice to have shoes that look good. I like to have a clean, professional appearance, so I look for shoes that strike a balance between being functional and looking presentable. If they can add a bit of personal style while meeting the comfort and support needs, that's definitely a bonus.

That's understandable. It sounds like finding the right balance between functionality and appearance is important to you.

How do you feel when you wear a pair of shoes that you consider both stylish and comfortable?

When I find that perfect pair that is both stylish and comfortable, it really boosts my confidence. I feel more put-together and it gives me a little extra pep in my step, knowing I’m not sacrificing comfort for style. It’s a nice feeling to have shoes that look good and make it easier to get through a busy day.

It sounds like having shoes that meet both your style and comfort needs has a positive impact on your overall mood and confidence. 

Can you share an experience when your shoes received comments from colleagues or patients? How did those comments affect your perception of the shoes?

Sure! I remember wearing a new pair of shoes to work that were both comfortable and had a bit of flair. A couple of colleagues mentioned how nice they looked and asked where I got them. It definitely gave me a confidence boost and made me feel positive about my choice. Having others notice and appreciate the balance of style and function reinforces that I'm making the right choices in my footwear.

That's great to hear! It seems like positive feedback from others can enhance your perception of your footwear choices.

How do you balance comfort and style when selecting shoes for work?

I usually start by prioritizing comfort features like arch support, cushioning, and a snug fit that won’t cause blisters. Once I’ve narrowed down options that meet those criteria, I look for styles that match my professional appearance and personal taste. If I find a pair that has all the comfort features I need and also looks good, that’s when I know I’ve found a winner. It’s all about finding that middle ground where I don’t have to compromise on either aspect.

Thank you for explaining your approach to balancing comfort and style. It’s clear that both aspects are essential to you, with comfort being the primary factor.

Now, let's talk more about the functional side of things. What specific features do you look for in a nursing shoe for comfort and support?

When it comes to nursing shoes, I look for a few key features. Good arch support is a must since it helps reduce foot fatigue. I also look for cushioning that absorbs shock, which is really helpful during long shifts. A sturdy, non-slip sole is important for safety, especially in hospital environments where floors can sometimes be wet. Additionally, I prefer shoes that are breathable to keep my feet cool and dry, and lightweight enough so they don’t feel like they’re weighing me down by the end of the day.

Those are all important features to keep your feet comfortable and protected during your shifts. 

How do you assess the durability of a pair of shoes before purchasing?

Before purchasing, I usually check the materials and construction of the shoes. I look for high-quality materials that are known for durability, like leather or sturdy synthetic fabrics. I also pay attention to the stitching and seams, making sure they look well-made and not likely to come apart easily. If possible, I read reviews to see how others have found the durability over time. Sometimes, just feeling the shoe's weight and structure gives a good indication of how well it's likely to hold up.

That makes a lot of sense, and it sounds like you have a thorough approach to evaluating durability.

What are the common issues you face with shoes in terms of functionality while on the job?

Some common issues I face include shoes wearing out too quickly, especially in the cushioning and soles. Sometimes, the grip on the soles doesn't live up to expectations, which can be a safety concern on slick hospital floors. I've also experienced shoes that start to lose shape or support after a few weeks, which can make them uncomfortable for my feet. It’s frustrating when a pair seems great at first but doesn’t stand the test of everyday use.

Thank you for sharing these common issues; it's illuminating to hear about the challenges with durability and functionality.

How long do your work shoes typically last before you consider replacing them?

Typically, I find myself needing to replace my work shoes every six months to a year. It really depends on the brand and how well they hold up to daily wear and tear. If I notice they're losing support or starting to cause discomfort, that's usually my cue to start looking for a new pair.

Got it, that sounds quite reasonable given the demands of your job.

Now, looking at the broader environment, how do environmental factors at your workplace influence your footwear choice?

The hospital environment definitely plays a big role in my footwear choice. Floors can be hard and sometimes wet, so slip-resistant soles are crucial to prevent any accidents. There's also a lot of walking on tile or linoleum, which requires shoes with proper cushioning and support to handle the hard surfaces. Additionally, the need for easy-to-clean materials is important, considering the potential for spills and the necessity of maintaining cleanliness. These factors really guide me in selecting shoes that are practical and safe for my work environment.

It’s clear that your workplace environment significantly impacts your footwear choices, ensuring both safety and practicality.

Can you describe a situation where a change in your work environment led to a change in your footwear preference?

Certainly! When I first transitioned to working in a hospital with a larger, busier ward, I noticed my previous shoes weren’t holding up to the increased walking and long shifts. The added movement and the larger area to cover meant I needed shoes with even better support and durability. That experience led me to invest in a pair that was specifically designed for high-impact, long-duration wear, which made a noticeable difference in my comfort and energy levels throughout the day.

Thank you for sharing that specific instance. It's interesting to see how changes in your work environment directly impacted your footwear needs.

Are there any seasonal changes that affect your choice of shoes for work?

Yes, definitely. In the colder months, I might lean towards shoes with a bit more insulation to keep my feet warm during my commute. I always make sure they're still breathable, though, for indoors. During the rainy season here in Seattle, I look for shoes with better water resistance to handle the wet weather. No matter the season, though, the core features like comfort and slip-resistance stay a priority.

That makes perfect sense given your location and the demands of your job.

Now, moving on to the perception of brands, how much does brand reputation influence your decision when purchasing shoes for work?

Brand reputation does play a role in my decision, mainly because I tend to trust brands that have a history of making high-quality and comfortable products. A good reputation often indicates that the shoes will meet my needs for support and durability. However, I also consider other factors like customer reviews and personal recommendations from colleagues. If a less well-known brand has shoes that tick all my boxes, I'm open to giving them a try.

It's great that you keep an open mind while also considering brand reputation. 

Can you think of a brand whose shoes you preferred or avoided? Why?

I usually prefer brands like Dansko or New Balance because they have a solid reputation for comfort and support, and I've had good experiences with their shoes holding up over time. On the other hand, I've avoided some trendy brands that focus more on style than functionality because, based on past experiences, they don't always provide the support I need for long shifts.

Thank you for sharing those preferences and the reasons behind them. It’s quite insightful.

How do you gather information about different shoe brands before making a purchase?

I typically start by reading online reviews to see what others have experienced with the shoes. I look for reviews that mention comfort, durability, and support, specifically from other nurses or people who are on their feet a lot. I also value recommendations from colleagues who might have firsthand experience with a brand or style I'm considering. Occasionally, I’ll visit stores to try on different pairs and get a feel for them myself.

That sounds like a thorough and well-rounded approach to gathering information and making informed decisions.

Turning to what prompts your purchases, what usually prompts you to buy a new pair of work shoes?

I usually start considering a new pair when I notice my current shoes have lost their support or cushioning, like if they start causing discomfort or pain during a shift. Visible wear and tear, like worn-out soles or fraying fabrics, also signal it's time for a change. Sometimes, if I find a good sale or hear strong recommendations about a particular shoe, I might be prompted to make a purchase a bit sooner than planned.

Thank you for explaining those prompts. It sounds like both performance and external factors influence your decision to buy new shoes.

When considering a new pair, what aspects do you prioritize most?

When considering a new pair, I prioritize comfort and support above all. Shoes need to have strong arch support and cushioning to keep me comfortable through long shifts. Durability is also crucial, to ensure they can withstand the demands of my job. Lastly, I consider slip resistance for safety on hospital floors, and if the style is nice and professional, that’s a plus, but secondary to the functional needs.

It's clear that your primary focus is on the functional aspects of comfort, support, and durability, with style as an added bonus.

Have you ever had an emotional reaction that led to a change in your footwear choice? Can you describe it?

Yes, there was a time when I had several long and challenging shifts in a row, and my feet were really feeling the strain. It got to the point where the discomfort was affecting my mood and patience, both at work and at home. That frustration made me realize I needed to prioritize finding a better pair of shoes immediately, even if it meant spending a bit more than usual. I ended up choosing a pair with enhanced comfort features, and it made a noticeable difference in how I felt throughout the day.

Thank you for sharing that experience. It highlights the significant impact that proper footwear can have on not just physical comfort but overall well-being.

Moving on to current frustrations, what are your current frustrations with the available footwear options for nurses?

One frustration is finding a pair that maintains its support and comfort over time. Some shoes start off great but quickly wear down with daily use. Another issue is price; high-quality supportive shoes tend to be quite expensive, and it can be tough justifying the cost when needing replacements fairly often. Lastly, while some brands focus on function, they might lack in style, making it hard to find shoes that strike a balance between professional appearance and the comfort required for long shifts.

I can understand how those frustrations can pose significant challenges for you. 

Can you think of specific features or attributes you wish were available in nursing shoes?

I wish nursing shoes had more durable cushioning technology that lasts longer without breaking down, ensuring consistent comfort over time. It would also be great to see more options that combine style with functionality, so I don't have to sacrifice one for the other. Additionally, shoes that offer customizable fit options, like adjustable insoles or arch support, would be a huge benefit for catering to individual needs. Lastly, increasing the range of affordable options without compromising on quality would be fantastic.

Those are thoughtful suggestions that address both functionality and personal preferences.

What would trigger you to switch to a new brand or model of nursing shoes?

I’d consider switching if I consistently heard positive feedback from colleagues or read reviews that praised a new brand's comfort and durability. An innovative design that promises better support or longer-lasting comfort could also catch my attention, especially if it addresses specific issues like reducing foot soreness after long shifts. Additionally, a good sale or more affordable pricing for high-quality shoes might prompt me to try something new.

Thank you for those insights. It's helpful to understand what factors could influence a change in your footwear choice.

To wrap things up, is there anything else you’d like to share that we haven’t covered today?

I think we’ve covered most of it, but I’d add that it’s important for shoe designers and brands to understand the day-to-day realities of being on your feet all day in a healthcare environment. Small details can make a big difference in comfort and performance, so keeping the real-world experiences of nurses in mind will always be key. Thanks for giving me the opportunity to share my thoughts!

Thank you, Morgan, for sharing your valuable insights and experiences. They will be incredibly helpful for our study.

Do you have any specific ideas for improvements in the design of nursing shoes that we haven't already discussed?

One idea that comes to mind is integrating more breathable materials while keeping the shoes easy to clean. This would help keep feet dry and comfortable during long shifts without compromising hygiene. Also, incorporating smart design features like pressure-mapped zones for targeted cushioning and support could be beneficial. Having a modular or customizable element, like removable or adjustable insoles, could help accommodate different foot shapes and preferences. These improvements would add both comfort and practicality to nursing shoes.

Those are excellent suggestions, Morgan.

Are there any questions you expected to be asked that we did not cover?

I think we pretty much covered everything I expected. We've touched on comfort, durability, style, and even the challenges and improvements I’d like to see. It’s been a comprehensive discussion, and I appreciate the chance to share my thoughts. If there’s anything else you need, feel free to ask!
